title: How to Make the Last Word (Cocktail)

steps.headline: Measure out 0.75 fluid ounces (22 ml) of green chartreuse into the appropriate jigger.
steps.description: Pour into the shaker. Chartreuse is a French liqueur that has been made by Carthusian Monks since 1737. This ingredient adds the distinctive green color, as well as the sweet, herbal, and spicy tastes.

This liqueur is obtained from distilling cherries from the marasca cherry trees. It adds a strong, sweet cherry flavor and aroma with a smooth finish.

steps.headline: Measure out 0.75 fluid ounces (22 ml) of gin into the appropriate jigger.

text:
Measure out 0.75 fluid ounces (22 ml) of green chartreuse into the appropriate jigger. Pour into the shaker. Chartreuse is a French liqueur that has been made by Carthusian Monks since 1737. This ingredient adds the distinctive green color, as well as the sweet, herbal, and spicy tastes. Measure out 0.75 fluid ounces (22 ml) of maraschino liqueur into the appropriate jigger. Pour into the shaker
This liqueur is obtained from distilling cherries from the marasca cherry trees. It adds a strong, sweet cherry flavor and aroma with a smooth finish. Measure out 0.75 fluid ounces (22 ml) of gin into the appropriate jigger. Pour into the shaker. Gin is a spirit made with juniper berries. The herbal flavors complement those of the chartreuse. This ingredient makes The Last Word a gin-based cocktail. Squeeze fresh lime juice. Cut a lime in half and juice it using a citrus juicer; you may want to juice extra so you can enjoy more than one drink. Measure out 0.75 fluid ounces (22 ml) of the freshly squeeze lime juice into the jigger. Pour into the shaker. Add a scoop of ice, enough to cover the liqueurs, into the shaker.  Shake enthusiastically.  Pour into cocktail glass. Strain the contents of the shaker into your cocktail glass of choice. This cocktail is typically presented in a stemmed cocktail glass Garnish. From the lime, peel a rectangular strip of the peel of desired length. Gently coil the peel, and place on the rim of the glass. Use a full lime to create the garnish to prevent any mess, as you may need to provide some pressure when peeling the lime. Serve. Simply enjoy the cocktail or present it to your guests!
